comment._content: On February 4, 1914 (the date on this photo) former Congressman Lucius Littauer, a wealthy glove manufacturer from Gloversville, New York, was in court, pleading guilty to a charge of smuggling. He and his brother (and partner-in-crime) paid fines, but their prison sentences were suspended. Several New York officials declared Littauer eligible to continue serving as a member of the New York State Board of Regents (Department of Education), but at the next meeting of the Regents, he resigned that position. Littauer and his brother had smuggled a valuable tiara into the country, without paying customs duty. "Littauers Enter Pleas of Guilty" New York Times story, February 4, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E06EEDA1730E7... "Littauers Pay Fine, But Escape Prison" New York Times story, February 5, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B02E5D71F3BE6... The District Attorney thought that conviction meant that the Littauer brothers had surrendered rights of citizenship. New York Times story, February 6, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9501E4DE113FE6... "Littauer Still A Regent" New York Times story, February 12, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9F05E... "Littauer Out As Regent" A follow-up story, NYT, February 27, 1914, reports Littauer's resignation from the New York Board of Regents: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B01E6DE163AE6...
